utterances: And so, you don't know.
We don't know, as of right now, but I think I have a pretty good shot.
Well, two out of three, so at least that much, yeah.
How long have you been working towards this goal?
Just about 22 years, now
(Soundbite of laughter
That's a long time.
Definitely, yes.
And again, just remind listeners, what's your day like, a typical Tuesday, not at the Olympic trials, but just a typical Tuesday?
Well, I live out here at the Olympic Training Center at Colorado Springs.
I live on complex.
And I normally have two practices a day.
I'll wake up around nine in the morning, get worked on by the trainers and doctors.

I'll normally have about a two and a half to three hour practice in the morning, rest up in the afternoon, have some lunch, go back for another two and a half to three hours at night, and then do some recovery activities.
Basically, the whole day is structured around practice and recovery to make sure that I'm ready for each practice, each day.
And if you've been doing it for more than 20 years, you started as a young boy
Yeah, I started when I was six years old.
And is it important?
Do you have to start when you're that young?
Gymnastics is a sport that it takes a long time to develop.
You won't find too many people in the top level that start, you know, in high school or in college.
It really is a sport that takes a long time.
So, most people that get to this level do start very young.
And I guess I have to ask you, if it works out that way and you don't get to go to Beijing, this could be your one chance, you never know, injury, a lot of things can happen in four years time.
Will all of it have been worth it, even if you don't get the chance to go?
Absolutely.
Without a doubt, it has all been worth it.
I've gotten to travel the world.
I've seen most places that people will never get a chance to see.
I've met incredible people, made some amazing friends.
And to compete for the United States - I've been fortunate enough to be part of the U.S.
National Team for the past six years - and to go out and compete with the U.S.A.
on your chest is an honor that most people will never get a chance to feel.
And whether or not I get to compete in Beijing, I'll still have that, you know, for the rest of my life.
And I'm really proud about that.
Let's get a caller on the line.
And this is Theresa.
Theresa with us from Santa Fe, in California.
Hi.
Hi, Theresa.
I have kind of a different perspective on all of this.
I was a synchronized swimmer in Santa Clara, and our sport was a demonstration sport for several of the Olympics, including the one in Munich, which I got to go to, and - with my teammates.

And here we were, thinking, wow, you know, we're not at the Olympics yet, but we're being included, and then the tragedy that followed just - it was just kind of a different - there was the joy, and then there was the reality of that happening at the same time
Of course, that was the Olympics where Israeli athletes were first kidnapped and later murdered.
Yeah, that's right.
But the interesting thing was the next year, our sport was put into the World Aquatic Championships, and it's been included ever since.
And then several of my teammates and I went - we had to have 15 countries, I believe, the minimum in order to have it be an Olympic sport.
So I went to Germany and South Africa and coached.
I had friends who went to Japan and Canada and Switzerland.
And so we all had to kind of fan out in the '70s in order to bring the sport up to a level where it would be considered a verifiable sport at the Olympic level.
Synchronized swimming is kind of the Rodney Dangerfield of sports.
It doesn't get a lot of respect
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, but - you know, strangely enough now, the finals are one of the most highly attended of any Olympic finals, so it's kind of - it was nice.
It was an adventurous youth to have.
An adventurous youth.
Yes.
And a lot of traveling, and you do get to see a lot of the world.
Yes, it definitely is.
The way we select our team now is we have four days of qualification over two competitions, our U.S.
Nationals, and then we have our Olympic trials, which we just had in Philadelphia a couple of weeks ago.
And after that, we total up all the scores and there's a committee of five guys that look over all the scores and take in a bunch of different things into account.
And then they select the team according to how they think, you know, the top six guys would fit into that.
It's like a big puzzle.
Even if you finish in the top, it doesn't necessarily guarantee a spot onto the team.
And that's - since it's inevitably not objective, it's got to be something of a disappointment when you figure there can't be all that much difference between you and the next guy.
Yeah, but you know, we go into it knowing that that's the way that our sport is.
We understand that those guys have a very difficult task in selecting the team.
I don't envy their position.
It's very, very difficult.
And you know, we do everything we can to be selected, and in the end, we leave it up to them.
And that's all we can do.
Let's get another caller on the line.
This is Susan.
Susan's calling us from Syracuse, in New York
Hello.
Hi, Susan.
You're on the air.
Hi.
I've never trained for an Olympic, but when I hear them talking so often about the sacrifice they make and all these things that they do, I'm not sure that they're sacrifices.
I believe that it's almost gotten to a point of an addiction, that people let everything else fall aside, families and friend.
They don't develop normal lives.
They completely self-immerse in this.
Now, I'm not against this, but I wonder why it's exalted this, you know, the finest thing, the number one thing to be able to do.
And if you don't do it and you fall short, often they feel a sense of failure, when certainly a silver medal can't be considered a failure by anyone.
Yeah.
Do you understand the point I'm making?
Yeah.
I'm going to - just let me ask David Durante.
First of all, do you think you've had to make sacrifices, and do you think this is in any way an obsession?
Well, I think that anything worth going after in life you have to make sacrifices for.
Probably the biggest sacrifice I've had to make with gymnastics is being away from my family for so long.
They mean the world to me.
But along with that is that they've been able to share in all of the great parts of what I've been able to do with gymnastics.
So, I mean, in any great thing that you go after in your life, sacrifices are needed.
And in terms of it being an obsession, there's probably an aspect to it where you have to be obsessed to get to the top level.
I'm not going to deny that.
I'm definitely a perfectionist in that sense.
But I really think that it's worth it in the end.
And you know, if you're willing to go after that, you have to make certain things a priority.
And I think that Olympians do that.
Thank you, Susan, for the phone call.
Appreciate it.
You're welcome.
Bye-bye.
Joining us now from training camp in Knoxville, Tennessee, is Laura Wilkinson.
She's the 2000 Olympic gold medalist in women's platform diving.
She's also a member of the 2008 Olympic diving team.
And Laura, thanks very much for being with us.
Thanks for having me.
And obviously, you've been a competitive diver for quite some time.
Yeah.
About 15 years.
And again, we're asking athletes at this level about their regimens, their day.
What's a normal Tuesday for you?
Well, normally when we're at home, we work out between six and eight hours a day.
We do both water work and what we call dry land, which is stretching and somersaulting and trampoline work and, you know, abs and plyos and Pilates, things like that.
That's an awful lot of work.
That's a fulltime job.
Yep.
